Award.AwardTitle: Rapid Evolution and the Dynamics of Complex Ecological Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecological processes and evolution have long been viewed as occurring on radically different time scales, but studies over the last three decades have compellingly shown that evolutionary change often occurs at the same time and pace as ecological dynamics. Species as diverse as algae, annual plants, birds, fishes, insects, and sheep have quickly undergone evolutionary changes when their environments change or when they invade a new habitat. This project will use mathematical and statistical studies of model ecological food webs to understand how the coupling of ecology and evolution affects the temporal dynamics of species and their ability to persist in ever-changing environments, and how loss of genetic variability and the capacity for rapid evolutionary response may affect the robustness and stability of ecological systems. Statistical methods based on techniques for estimating smooth functions will be developed to infer evolutionary dynamics from observational population data such as ongoing monitoring of harvested or threatened species.

Becoming somebody's dinner, or the factory for replicating a virus, is very strong natural selection. It is hard to imagine these occurring without immediate evolutionary consequences, but exactly that thinking is embedded in the ecological theory now underpinning environmental and natural resource management. Implications of this research are therefore extremely broad, including resource management, biodiversity conservation, invasive species management, and ecosystem responses to environmental change. Broader impacts also include training graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher, and using established contacts with environmental agencies to promote consideration of evolutionary dynamics in conservation planning and response to changing environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Within the last two decades, ecologist have discovered that evolutionary change often happens within much shorter time periods than was previously believed: within a few generations, or even faster when extreme events (such as an emerging disease) cause high mortality. This means that ecological dynamics – succession after disturbance, spread of invasive species, the rise and fall of predator and prey populations, etc. – are complicated by the fact that the “rules of the game” constantly change. For example, cane toads, an invasive species spreading in Australia, have evolved longer legs in populations near the margin of the spreading population, but not in longer-occupied areas. There are now dozens of similar examples where important ecological processes are strongly affected by rapid evolution of organismal traits, and the study of such “eco-evolutionary dynamics” has become a major topic in ecological journals and professional meetings. 

This change in our view of how ecological systems work means that much of predictive ecological theory has to be rebuilt from the bottom up. Predator-prey models can’t just track the abundances of predators and prey (the numbers of moose and wolves in a forest, for example); they also need to keep track of how prey and predator traits evolve as (for example) increases in predator abundance create natural selection for prey traits that reduce predation risk. Similarly, analysis of observational data on ecological dynamics (e.g., long-term population records) has to be based on models that allow for the possibility that the “rules of the game” are changing as species evolve in response to natural selection.

This project tackled both of those challenges. One important contribution to ecological theory was to show how the theory of slow-fast dynamical systems could be used to simplify models of eco-evolutionary dynamics by reducing their dimension. We used these results to study: a general predator-prey system with rapid prey or predator evolution; predator-prey coevolution; and the ecological effects of inducible prey defense traits. We also showed that when prey evolve in response to two predators rather than one, new distinctive patterns occur that are impossible without prey evolution. These new theoretical predictions for a two predator, one prey food web were tested and confirmed experimentally in aquatic microcosms with rotifer and flagellates as predators and single-celled algae as prey (these experiments received partial support from this project). A simple method based on statistical “analysis of variance” was developed to measure the ecological importance of rapid evolution, by comparing the contributions of ecological or environmental change versus trait evolution to the changes in an ecological response variable. This method extended previous work by the same investigators by allowing for both inherited and environmentally-induced trait changes, and the new method could be applied to many more empirical studies of rapid evolution. The results from these applications have important implications for the potential role of evolutionary adaptation to climate change. They showed that “evolutionary rescue” (adaptation that is rapid enough compensate for a decline in environmental conditions) is common and is sometimes completely successful, but often it is not (e.g., evolutionary change reduced the harmful impact of environmental change by only about 30%). 

Contributions to data analysis included both basic methods and applications.
